The biggest draw is definitely the storyline and characters and while the gameplay wasn’t amazing it was solid enough to go hand in hand with the excellent story. What an ending as well.  It’s sitting at £20 on Steam right now but it’s regularly on sale and definitely worth adding to your Steam collection.

Apparently... after blowing up a beautiful city flying because of a miracle of physics, kidnapping and seducing a young girl, and killing everyone in the process... I am still the good guy... 

This game was quite an interesting go on parallel universes. I have to admit I did not fully understand every thing but I think I got the big picture. 

One of the interesting parts for me was the ego view, in which your character still talks. you don't get much of a say in it.
You may do some minor decisions, but still I don't think anything really changes, no matter what you do.

After a while the battles got a little boring for me... you either are slaughtering them all in the numbers... or you are a two shot for the bigger ones. But that may be the case, because I played on the highest difficulty. Some enemies, like the "Handyman" are quite frustrating in the case, that even their weakspot takes more ammo than you can carry around. And if you die ones they get healed by even more. 

Yet it stayed challenging and the enemies make the game really atmospheric. 

I won't compare it to the other parts, because for me the charm of Bioshock 1 & 2 was the dark, theme, everything was in some tight spot and there was no airway to the destination, while in Bioshpock infinite everything was way more open and you felt more free overall.

Last to be said I really missed the Big Daddies, but the one thing that tends to satisfy me more on this game is that you finally are meeting people, instead of talking to them over the radio.

Took 12 hours for the main campaign, I will play the DLCs next and refer to them in an extra review.

I can't believe I waited so long to play this utterly fantastic game.

The graphics are specatular, the sound is wonderful, the world is (like Bioshock 1) fully fleshed-out and immersive.  The vigors and gunplay is entertaining and challenging.  The story is a "page turner", with believable characters, excellent voice acting, and an ending that doesn't fall flat like so many other video games.  

Some people have remarked that this game is too hard.  I tried it on "hard", first, and found I couldn't make it past about the 2/3rds mark without sigificant deaths.  I then restarted, kept it on "hard," and completed the game finding it to be pleasantly challenging, but not "hard."  The secret for me was to focus my upgrades into a few vigors and guns I found complementary my playstyle (possession, crows, and later bronco; for guns, carbine, shotgun, rpg, and later, hand cannon and machine gun), as opposed to spreading the cash around too thinly, too early.  Regular use of vigors and appropriate management of clothing perks also helps, especially the invulnerability on/off of skylines.  With this approach, I died only 3 times in the whole "hard" playthrough.

I think this is now on my short list for possible G.O.A.T.

This game is a disappointment in comparison to the previous ones.  If you play mainly for the combat, that might be alright, but there's a few things to note.  The game has no manual save; it just uses "checkpoints" and a resurrection system where you lose stuff.  Which is very annoying unless you're so good you never lose, or into frustration and tedium.  It has its supporters but there's nothign FORCING you to use a manual save if it's there, and there could be a trophy for completion entirely using checkpoints, if you're in to that sort of thing.

Also, you can only carry two weapons at a time.  More realistic perhaps, although some of the heavier ones probably weigh more than two light ones, and you have a completely separate ammo budget for each one.  And if you're going for a bit of realism, you'd have to lose the skylines with their seventy-foot leaps and drops altogether.

The plot roars along for a while, but at the end it deteriorates rapidly into a mystic muddle rather like a certain Mass Effect game I might mention, utterly unlike the exemplary plotting of Bioshock one and two.

So I would say the game is diverting, but not worth it at this price.  If you are going to play it, probably worth reading a strategy guide along with it.

Slightly horrifying and vomit-inducing at rare times, but if you can stomach those moments, the rest is fine. It's a story I still can't explain to any family members due to time-consumption and the fact that I don't get it myself, but if you're just in it for the action it's simple - you gamble, you lose, you get hired to get a girl, you travel through a floating city, you kill anyone who shows racism, you get more guns, you get magic and you hopefully get payed at the end.

A very enjoyable time finding lots of inventive ways to kill people who deserve to die anyway. No complaints in gameplay, and it's visually stunning. Also one of the only games that my laptop hasn't had any problems with. Looking forward to getting Burial at Sea.

So after going through the whole timeline in the game after completing it, i switched from being quite impressed about the story and the game as a whole, to confused and baffled as there are so many things here that dont make sense at all. 
Example: 

[spoiler]Drowning Booker wouldnt solve anything as the game wants us to belive that all Bookers that can become Comstuck or Elizabeth's father will die at this point which in its self is nothing more than a massive contradiction. If she drowns Booker before the baptism then she cant be born to go back in time and drown her own father[/spoiler]

This is just one example of countless of things that dont make sense in the game. When you play through it for the first time things like that might seem cool and interesting even thought they are confusing at first, but thats the thing, the story as a whole is confusing because it doesnt make sense at all.

If a game intoduces things like time travel and multiple realities then i expect the devs to at least know how these concepts would work instead of using them in a cheap way by jumbling them together to form such a big mess of ideas and pushing them down the players throat to make him/her feel like the plot is much deeper then it actually is. 
Without a plot that makes sense this game is nothing more than a on-rails (no pun intended) first person shooter with poor balancing and little to no interesting mechanics which is kind of sad because that was not at all my first impression of the game.

This game... oooooh this game. I cannot express with words how I feel towards this game. This game is the best example of video games as an art form, and I could not pick a better contender if I tried. I could have said any of the Galactic Cafe games, or a Souls game, but this game has lots of engaging gameplay unlike walking simulators. This game has more of a storyt than just tatters of a story strung together by vague dialogue and item descriptions like Dark Souls. This game... it's in a league of it's own. It's in a league occupied solely by Bioshock Infinte.

Bioshock Infinite, like its predecessors, is a FPS developed by Irrational Games. It is about a distopian theocracy where the main character is sent to retrieve a young girl by the name of Elizabeth. A lot of unimportant stuff happens, you get targeted by the police force, everyone's attacking you for a while, yadda, yadda. And then you actually meet the other half of the focal point of this game: Elizabath. I'm going to skip the rest of the plot beacause you really, REALLY need to experience the rest of the plot for yourself. All I can tell you is that the story alone is worth the price of admission. Every character has motivations, goals, personalities, social ties, morals, philosophies, purpose. The characters are amazingly fleshed out to the point of feeling real. And trust me, you'll soon wish they were.

The graphics and music in this game are absolutely marvellous. I (finally) finished the original Bioshock recently, and noticed that, compared to Infinte, which I had played before, Bioshock had a very drab and uninteresting enviroment. With pile of rubble here or there, smeared blood every five feet, whether it be on the walls, floor, ceiling, glass, table, Steve from accounting, you name it. The colors are very dark and often blend together. Both games look stylized, but the difference was that the palettes of Infinte are much brighter, and (most) areas are in sunlight and not ruined. While I still really liked Bioshock above many other games I've played, the enviroment's coloring dragged its quality down for me a lot. But this isn't a review of Bioshock, now is it? The music compliments the enviroments beautifly, and while they reuse certain 'battle music' all the time during gameply, you will probably regard it more as an enemy signal than background music.

And now, for the gameplay. Frankly, I think this is the weakest part of the game. It's still a solid part of the game, but it gets overshadowed by a mile by its other components. I think this is the part of the game that I liked the original Bioshock for better. You can only hold two weapons at a time, and my god are there weapons. I think there are something like 15 or 16 weapons in this game, and you can only carry two. Sure, it makes more sense, but in the original Bioshock (I swear, I'll stop referencing Bioshock now) you carried a wrench, a pistol, a tommy gun, a shotgun, a grenade luancher, a camera, a flame/liquid nitrogen/electric-ooze-stuffthrower, a crossbow, AND THE AMMO FOR ALL OF THAT. I just find it wierd that they limit you to two when you have the oppurtunity to add WAY more guns to the players arsenal. The enemy AI is usually ok, leaning on the side of stupid rather than advanced. That said, even on normal, they can seriously pack a punch. This game isn't frustrating, but it is certainly hard. I'm a veteran gamer through and through, but even I died a good amount in this game. There are definetly parts that I might not have been able to get through without exploiting a few vigors and guns. Oh yeah, plasmids are still a thing, only they're called vigors now. I thought some of them are cool, but a majority of them feel useless. Also, Elizabeth helps you during battle. She isn't a liabilty, because she always seem to find cover and doesn't thow herself into enemy fire like some "companions" in other games. She throws you ammo, health, and salts (EVE). Like I said, gameplay's the weakest link of a adamantium chain.

[quote=][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/12146432-La-Cruceta-Inquieta/][b]La Cruceta Inquieta[/b][/url], mentor de Steam[/quote]

Uno entre un millón. Eso es lo que se te viene a la mente al finalizar un juego como el que nos ocupa. Y es que, ya desde su primera entrega, la saga Bioshock supo ofrecer una experiencia que iba más allá de lo que normalmente estamos acostumbrados a encontrar en un videojuego, acercándose en mayor medida a otros medios de expresión como el cine. No obstante, las dos primeras entregas (recordemos que la segunda no fue desarrollada por Irrational Games, la desarrolladora original) seguían en gran medida atadas al "gameplay" y las mecánicas tradicionalmente necesarias en un videojuego. Es con esta tercera entrega cuando, a pesar de aún no haber sido capaz de superar este conflicto, Bioshock hace de la narración de los acontecimientos el eje central de su desarrollo, acercando la saga en mayor medida a lo que nos ofrece el séptimo arte.

Al mismo tiempo que evoluciona en el aspecto narrativo, también Infinite lo hace en cuanto a la localización donde ésta acontece, pasando de la ciudad sumergida de Rapture de las dos primeras entregas a la ciudad sobre las nubes de Columbia. La fórmula anterior ya había sido exprimida y por ello ahora una nueva localización permite la creación de un nuevo mundo que, sin embargo, permanece siendo regido por reglas y personajes similares. La base reconocible de Bioshock queda intacta, conservándose la utopía, el abuso de poder y los conflictos morales, pero mostrándose en un nuevo escenario que añade lo necesario para que en absoluto pensemos estar repitiendo experiencias pasadas. De hecho, y es de agradecer en una industria que tiende en demasía a la repetición, Infinite parece un juego totalmente distinto que, sin embargo, no pierde las señas de identidad de la saga.

Como se ha comentado, la narrativa alcanza un nuevo nivel con Infinite, gracias en gran medida a la inclusión de un personaje clave en el desarrollo de la misma: Elizabeth. Este nuevo personaje nos acompañará durante la mayor parte de la aventura y, más allá de su utilidad dentro de la jugabilidad, constituye el verdadero motivo guía de la narración. Todo gira en torno a ella y, por ende, en torno a nosotros como sus protectores, incrementando hasta el extremo nuestra empatía hacia ella y, como consecuencia, también hacia lo que se nos está contando, logrando un mayor grado de implicación jugador-videojuego que en las anteriores entregas o, incluso, que en otros videojuegos. Aunque la ciudad como ente vivo sigue siendo importante, no lo es al nivel de Bioshock 1 y 2 y ahora se profundiza más en nuestra relación con terceras personas, en la toma de conciencia de la importancia e influencia de nuestros actos para con ellas y en la moralidad de los mismos.

En cuanto a la trama en sí misma, no pretendo bajo ningún concepto estropear a base de "spoilers" el disfrute de semejante esfuerzo narrativo y, por tanto, sólo no puedo dejar de mencionar el apoteósico final que nos espera al terminar Bioshock Infinite y por el que merece la pena no abandonar el juego en sus fases tempranas en el caso de que no sea de vuestro agrado (si es que algo así es posible).

A pesar de todo y como ya apuntaba al principio, el punto desgraciadamente más conflictivo de Infinite es que aún sigue atado a las cadenas del "gameplay". Soy consciente de que sigue siendo un videojuego y en ningún caso preferiría verlo convertido en un "walking simulator", una novela interactiva o algo similar, pero creo que no debo ser el único que, en cierta forma y en determinados momentos, vea que dicho "gameplay" llega a tornarse innecesario y convertirse en un lastre para la narración. No conozco la fórmula para solventar este problema, pero es algo decepcionante asistir a momentos trascendentales e impactantes que irremediablemente se ven salpicados por los requerimientos de una burda jugabilidad de "shooter". El final te deja maravillado, pero con la sensación de que algo ha fallado en alguna parte.

Los gráficos y la dirección artística son difícilmente mejorables y muy posiblemente soporten bien el paso del tiempo. Esta vez, al contrario que ocurría con la lúgubre ambientación de las dos entregas anteriores, Columbia se muestra como una ciudad llena de luz y color que enmascara la corrupción oculta en sus entrañas. También ahora se utiliza, frente al Art Decó de los originales, un estilo arquitectónico neoclásico que magnifica e ilumina los espacios desde una monumentalidad que busca empequeñecer al jugador en su relación con la ciudad como utopía que controla y vigila las vidas de sus ciudadanos. Y para concluir con los aspectos puramente gráficos o de diseño, esta monumentalidad en los escenarios se ve apoyada por la solidez de sus modelados y que también está presente en los de los personajes y objetos, además de haberse logrado de igual manera en los efectos gráficos y texturas.

La banda sonora tampoco se queda atrás en cuanto a ambientación, haciendo esta vez que determinadas composiciones formen parte de la narrativa e incluso de la jugabilidad. Dada esta situación, tampoco en esta ocasión conviene extenderse en su análisis para no estropear la experiencia de su integración en el "gameplay", pero sí puede decirse que composiciones clásicas, de la época y modernas se unen para crear estímulos puntuales que al final, en su conjunto, dan mayor sentido a los acontecimientos generales. También los efectos de sonido y las voces en v.o. cumplen de sobra dada su calidad y contribuyen a enfatizar la experiencia cinematográfica.

Por último, la jugabilidad, siendo uno de los aspectos que personalmente considero más controvertidos en Infinite, lo cierto es que ha sufrido un notable esfuerzo de adaptación al nuevo ritmo narrativo que en esta ocasión ha adoptado la saga. Pudiera decirse que, en los modos disponibles en un inicio, todo es más básico y fácil que en las dos entregas anteriores puesto que apenas hay penalización por morir, el sistema de recuperación de vida es más "amigable" y la reorganización y replanteamiento del sistema de poderes y armamento facilita en mucho nuestro avance. No obstante, todos estos cambios se entienden cuando, como ya se ha comentado en repetidas ocasiones, nos damos cuenta de que han sido reenfocados en virtud de la agilización de la narración. También en relación con esto, tal vez uno de los mayores aciertos de Infinite ha sido la inclusión de Elizabeth como personaje de apoyo pero del que únicamente deberemos preocuparnos en cuanto a su devenir narrativo, no al jugable. Se elimina así la tan tediosa y hasta aburrida y estresante labor de protección de personajes secundarios tan común en otros videojuegos hasta la fecha. Elizabeth es autosuficiente, nos ayuda dentro de sus posibilidades y no tenemos que hacer nada por ella excepto adentrarnos en su mundo y en su historia.

Llegados a este punto no voy a repetir el porqué de que el gameplay llegue a parecerme algo casi irrelevante en esta entrega, pero, si nos olvidamos de ello, lo cierto es que como "shooter" cumple perfectamente y es entretenido, pero, sin saber qué otra cosa pudiera ser, no es lo que un juego como Infinite pide ser para poder desplegarse en todo su esplendor.

Para concluir, tal vez en un videojuego de tal calibre argumental hubiera de haberse hecho un análisis más enfocado hacia la narrativa, pero es tal la experiencia de descubrirlo por uno mismo que he creído mejor no hacer prácticamente mención al respecto. Bioshock Infinite ha sabido evolucionar desde sus inicios para, conservando la personalidad que hizo exitosas a sus anteriores entregas, ofrecer una experiencia totalmente nueva y que difícilmente puede olvidarse. Por obras como esta merece la pena (iba a decir jugar) experimentar las sensaciones que puede llegar a provocarnos un videojuego.

Love the Bioshock series...Just finished this one (and the Under the Sea add-ons).   I found the main game to be more fun then the DLC followed by Under the Sea Episode 1, with Episode 2 bringing up the rear in terms of fun for me.   I like to play these games on Easy or Normal settings to enjoy the setting and story, with a bit less worry about dying and redoing sections.  I enjoy clearing sections of the attackers, then spending time looking around.  The movement of people, birds, the conversations that go on around you really add depth to the world.  The games are fairly linear, but the main game feels open none the less.   The linear nature, and a helpful navigational aid, means you won't likely get very lost.  This was a plus for me. 

The DLC felt more linear.  Episode 2 was a bit less enjoyable for me as I felt the "stealth" mechanics meant a lot more running (crouching actually) through and area and moving along quickly, without as much time to just look at the scenary (with the exception of the opening sequence).   Still they were fun to play with the links to the prior games. 

Overall a fairly lengthy game, with added gameplay for those who what to track down all the bonus records, films, achievements throughout.  Highly recommend these.

[strike]结合海葬第一章剧情理解（大误）[/strike]

绝对的神作，所有说三代不如一代的都是耍流氓。两者对比，一代无非是占了先行者优势。三代在游戏画面，射击手感等技术上毫无疑问是全面超越一代的[strike]不超越还玩个屁啊[/strike],剧情上，在我看来，三代的叙事手法几乎已经达到线性叙事的巅峰。主角从海上进入哥伦比亚到被发现手上烙印的序章，完美诠释了什么才叫做电影化的游戏，与之相比，《教团》的表现简直就像小学生。

[h1]以下内容含轻量剧透，瞎扯居多[/h1]

然而，上面的赞美全都针对三代的本体，而不针对海葬两章dlc。不是说dlc做得不好，dlc还原了销魂城盛世时的景象，将两代剧情通过各种细节交织在一起[spoiler]其实也从某种角度反映出一代和三代从人设到剧情都真的挺像的[/spoiler]，对人性和选择的探讨，和最后招牌式的出乎意料的剧情反转，都是充满了诚意。

可是，两章dlc依然显得突兀。主要在于，它更改的原著的很多设定。比如，dlc里对戴西进行了洗白，把她威胁要杀男孩的行为解释成戴西必将在起义中死去，而戴西选择牺牲自己来唤起伊丽莎白心中杀手的本性（误）。dlc里的一段对话就把一个原本敢爱敢恨追求自由却又有点不择手段性格复杂的女汉子，变成了一个光辉正义舍己为人的圣母，实在是有点难以接受。

更重要的是，第二章的结局跟一代剧情是对不上的。最明显的一点是，第二章里面伊丽莎白为方汀找到了控制一代主角Jack的方法，然而在一代里，用来控制Jack的基因就是方汀植入的，方汀本来就知道控制Jack的方法。当然你可以用平行宇宙有无限可能，海葬与一代不是同一个宇宙来解释。然而海葬剧情的震撼感很大一部分来自于一代和三代剧情的完整串联，一个微小的决定就改变了无数人的命运。用平行宇宙来解释bug不但有强行洗地的感觉，更加弱化了海葬剧情的震撼力。

那这两章dlc为什么会存在？在我看来Ken Levin在制作前已经预料到工作室命不久矣。在结束一切之前，必须给玩家一个交代。两章dlc把生化奇兵系列穿成了完整的三部曲，同时也写死了三部的剧情，所有的伊丽莎白、所有的康斯托克都不再存在，无限的可能终归为一，生化奇兵系列就此结束。

[b][i]"The mind of the subject will desperately struggle to create memories where none exist..." - R. Lutece, 1889."[/i][/b]

[b]Historia[/b]

 Se você jogou outros BioShock's sabe que o enredo do jogo é muito bom, BioShock Infinite possui um enredo muito mais elaborado que seus antecessores, tudo nesse jogo vai fazer algum sentido uma hora, o enredo é complexo a uma grande chance de você não entender tudo de uma vez, tudo gira entorno da Elizabeth, ao contrario de outros jogos ela não é uma personagem feminina que esta ali só pra ser salvo pelo heroi, e sim a melhor personagem do jogo, ela é muito bem desenvolvida até melhor que o Booker, o vilão Comstock é muito bem construido dentro da trama do jogo, assim como Daisy Fitzroy e Robert e Rosalind Lutèce, tudo se encaixa perfeitamente, o jogo possui um enredo perfeito e que com certeza vai marcar todos aqueles que jogarem.

[b]Jogabilidade[/b]
 
 A jogabilidade de BioShock é diferente do que vemos em outros FPSs, ela é mais lenta e com menos ação do que vemos em jogos como Battlefield e Call of Duty, mas é dinamica, os poderes e armas combinados, usar o ambiente, tudo deixa a jogabilidade mais fluida, não temos que se preocupar com a Elizabeth sendo sequestrada e temos que resgatar, coisa que acontece em Resident Evil 4, ela nos ajuda, fornece munição e suprimentos que acabam facilitanto do jogo, tudo flui muito bem, mesmo não sendo um jogo rapido BioShock Infinite é muito fluido e dinamico sua jogabilidade é unica e que ira agradar todos jogadores.

[b]Gráfico e Ambientação[/b]

 O gráfico do jogo é muito lindo, possui seu estilo um pouco cartunesco, porem é muito bom, os reflexos, a iluminação, os inimigos, as armas, as estatuas tudo é muito bem feito, cade coisa reflete o estilo steampunk do jogo, assim como ambientação, o interior das casas lembra muito o estilo presente nos séculos XIX e XX, o exterior é muito bonito, desde as barraquinhas vendendo frutas a grandes monumentos, tudo é belíssimo e bem detalhada, cada coisa deixa Columbia mais viva, isso é um grande ponto positivo.

[b]Trilha Sonora, Sons e Dublagem[/b]

 As musicas são muito boas, temos uma pega a época que se passa o jogo, as musicas se encaixam muito bem, não só as da trilha sonora, mas também que tocam em radios e discos nos ambientes, isso também influencia no som do jogo que cade som esta no lugar certo, a dublagem é muito boa, as vozes combinam muito bem, além de ser muito bem sincronizadas, tudo é muito bom e com certeza isso é um quesito que não ira decepcionar, claro tudo nesse jogo é praticamente perfeito.

[b]Conclusão[/b]

 BioShock Infinite é um dos melhores jogos feitos, com excelente enredo e jogabilidade, e que com certeza você ira amar esse jogo, e ele ira marcar sua vida gamer.
